name: Contextual Retrieval With Sparse and Reranking

parameters.content:
## 2. Split Document Into Chunks
Unlike traditional vector store workflows, we want to split our document prior to embedding and this is easily achieved using the Code node. Feel free to adjust the text splitting params or replace it entirely to suit the needs of your data.

You may need to play around and adjust the chunksize for your particular data. Contextual retrieval as described in the article is expected to return 20 results so best to keep these small.

## 3. Generate Sparse Vector and Contextual Text For Chunk
With our chunks, we'll want to achieve the following:
(1) **Generate a contextual summary of what the chunk is about relative to the whole document**.
For this, we'll use the basic LLM node using Antrophic's Claude Haiku model with the recommended prompt as shared in the article.
(2) **Generate a sparse vector for the chunk and summary**
We can use the python code node to generate TF-IDF sparse vectors with the scikit-learn library. Good to know, this library doesn't require external dependency setup steps and auto-installs on first time use.

Once we have our generated values, we'll combine them with the chunk object using the Edit Fields node.

## 4. Insert Docs to Qdrant (via Langchain Code Node)
Unfortunately, n8n (or rather langchain) doesn't support inserting sparse vectors so we'll have to build our own "Insert Documents" node using a Langchain Code Node. In this Langchain code node, we'll forego the langchain vectorstore node and use the Qdrant client SDK directly instead.

**Note** To avoid duplication, this node will also delete existing vectors by document title. It does so by tagging each vector with the document title we extracted earlier then when run again, performs a Qdrant delete by filter before upserting.

**Required:**
To use this demonstration, you must complete the following:
* Ensure your Qdrant instance is running and set the URL in the node
* Create the Qdrant collection as instructed (see yellow sticky)

## 5. Retrieval using Sparse Vectors and ReRanker (Chat Agent Example)
For retrieval, we want to be able to (1) query with both dense and sparse vectors and (2) apply a rerank algorithm to our vector store docs. We can setup a custom vector store tool which does both using a custom Langchain Code node.

**Required:**
To use this demonstration, you must complete the following:
* Installed the updated version of the @Qdrant/js-client-rest module
* Ensure your Qdrant instance is running and set the URL in the "Qdrant with Cohere ReRank" subnode
* Add your Cohere API key in the "Qdrant with Cohere ReRank" subnode.

This demonstration is similar to the previous step but is not using an AI Agent.

**Required:**
To use this demonstration, you must complete the following:
* Installed the updated version of the @Qdrant/js-client-rest module
* Ensure your Qdrant instance is running and set the URL in the "Qdrant with Cohere ReRank1" node
* Add your Cohere API key in the "Qdrant with Cohere ReRank1" node.

## Implementing Antrophic's Contextual Retrieval 

This workflow is inspired by the Antrophic article, ["Introducing Contextual Retrieval"](https://www.anthropic.com/news/contextual-retrieval), and tries to replicate the instructions given.

**Original post here**: https://community.n8n.io/t/building-the-ultimate-rag-setup-with-contextual-summaries-sparse-vectors-and-reranking/54861/1
